<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Markets: </strong></span><span>We're experiencing what Wall Street wonks call a "</span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/09/stock-market-futures-open-to-close-news.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rotation</a></span><span>"—when investors sell off shares in a certain type of company and pile into another category. Because of the promising vaccine news on Monday, stocks that had been clobbered by the pandemic are looking more attractive...and vice versa. The tech-focused Nasdaq closed down for a second straight day while the Dow finished higher for a second straight day. </span>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
COVID
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/10/new-study-indicates-crowded-indoor-spaces-ripe-covid-transmission?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Covid Dines and Dashes
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Restaurant with Covid sign" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zMDgyL3Jlc3RhdXJhbnRfd2l0aF9jb3ZpZF9zaWduLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Jeffrey Greenberg/Education Images/Universal Images Group via Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Considering we can't even keep track of our wallets, it's not particularly surprising humans have struggled to understand how an invisible menace like the coronavirus spreads across the population.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But a <a href="https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-020-03140-4?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">study</a> published yesterday in Nature offers new clues about Covid-19's favorite places to jump hosts.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The main takeaways</h2>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Indoor spaces = the most risky. </strong></span><span>Crowded indoor venues, such as restaurants, gyms, and cafes, accounted for the majority of the transmission. Of those, restaurants were by far the riskiest place for infections (4x more dangerous than gyms and coffee shops), the report's senior author, Jure Leskovec, told reporters. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">The class divide: </strong></span><span>People who live in lower-income areas were also </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-11-10/covid-superspreader-risk-is-linked-to-restaurants-gyms-hotels?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">more likely</a></span><span> to be infected with Covid-19, according to the research. Not only were they less likely to work from home, but also the indoor venues they visited were more crowded. For example, the average grocery store in poorer neighborhoods had 59% more hourly visitors per sq. ft. than locations in more affluent areas. </span>
</li>
</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quick note on methodology: </strong>Using anonymized smartphone data, the researchers tracked the movements of 98 million people in 10 U.S. metros from March to May—the first wave of the virus. They superimposed this data on top of Covid-19 case numbers to <a href="http://washingtonpost.com/health/2020/11/10/coronavirus-restaurants-gyms-hotels-risk/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">create a model</a> that simulated coronavirus infections. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Why the study matters</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Because it can inform how leaders confront the recent surge in cases, which are now well above 100,000/day in the U.S. Should we lock it all down again? </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">These researchers argue that probably won't be necessary, because limiting capacity at indoor venues can meaningfully contain the spread of the virus—when paired with critical precautions like social distancing and wearing masks. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>In the Chicago area, limiting capacity at 20% cut down predicted new infections by more than 80%.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>On the other hand, reopening indoor businesses at full capacity = recipe for superspreading. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>While these researchers call for a nuanced approach to reopening the economy, public officials may find it easier to wield a blunt instrument. NYC Mayor Bill de Blasio <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/11/10/world/covid-19-coronavirus-live-updates?type=styln-live-updates&label=virus&index=0&action=click&module=Spotlight&pgtype=Homepage#research-using-spring-cellphone-data-in-10-us-cities-could-help-influence-officials-facing-rising-cases-and-possible-restriction&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">warned</a> of "a lot more restrictions" in the event of a second wave. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TECH
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/10/apple-breaks-intel-new-hardware-featuring-internally-created-chips?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Macs and Their Chips Think the Same Now
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="M1 chip" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zMDkwL20xX2NoaXAuanBlZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Apple</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, Apple <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/10/apple-event-live-updates.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ended</a> a 15-year relationship the way any rational person would: with a press conference. In a virtual event called "One More Thing," the tech giant released its latest slate of Mac computers featuring the M1 chips it created in-house—a major departure from tapping Intel for chips, which Apple had done since 2005. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>CEO Tim Cook has been steering the ship toward the Isle of Homemade Chips for years; the company <a href="https://www.cnet.com/news/apples-new-macbook-and-mac-mini-computers-could-change-pcs-as-we-know-them-one-more-thing-event-new-silicon/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">poured</a> over a decade of R&D and at least $1 billion in acquisitions into the effort. The M1 is more like the chips that power the iPhone than previous versions, which <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/11/10/heres-everything-apple-announced-at-the-one-more-thing-event-today/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">means</a> apps developed for iPhones can now be used on Macs. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Now for the fun, shiny things: </strong>The new hardware includes a super-thin MacBook Air, a new MacBook Pro with juiced-up battery life, and a Mac Mini desktop. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The new Big Sur OS also drops today.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Now for the fun, giggly things</strong>: Actor/comedian/national treasure John Hodgman <a href="https://www.cnet.com/news/apple-ends-mac-event-with-the-return-of-john-hodgman-as-the-pc-guy/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">returned</a> to his role as a PC in a skit made specially for the announcement. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RETAIL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/11/singles-day-test-chinas-consumer-demand?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Single and Ready to <span style="text-decoration: line-through;">Mingle</span> Spend All Our Money
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="The president of Taobao speaks at Alibaba's Global Shopping Festival in front of a pink, purple, and blue screen displaying sales from Singles Day in 2019. " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zMDg2L3NpbmdsZXNfZGF5LmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Alibaba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As you read this, legions of shoppers are breaking out their Alipay wallet to <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/stories/2020/11/09/singles-day-2020-retail-professionals-need-know?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">participate</a> in the world's biggest shopping event: Singles Day.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The annual Chinese shopping event features discounts on everything from robot vacuums to real estate and includes "shoppertainment," such as a gala with celeb performances, <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/10/singles-day-sales-to-get-tremendous-lift-from-livestream-events.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">livestreamed sales</a>, and <a href="https://www.scmp.com/abacus/tech/article/3108768/singles-day-mini-games-keep-shoppers-coming-back-more-taobao-and-jdcom?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">online games</a>.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Singles Day was created by Alibaba execs Jack Ma and Daniel Zhang as a foil to Valentine's Day. The date 11/11 was picked because it looks like "bare branches"—single and unattached. We feel even lonelier now. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Alibaba kicked sales off a little early this year, and as of 12:30am local time, <a href="https://apnews.com/article/travel-virus-outbreak-global-trade-shopping-hong-kong-62b6c606c4dff0d2b9914770883cf6dc?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">consumers spent</a> $56.3 billion on its Taobao and Tmall e-commerce platforms. To move all that product around, Alibaba's logistics arm has prepped 3,000 chartered flights and cargo ships, 3 million logistics workers, and 10,000 mobile lockers. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>The pandemic pushed more Chinese consumers to e-commerce, and Singles Day will provide more intel on the health of the Chinese economy. Given travel restrictions, imports and foreign luxury products are expected to perform well. </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/10/fed-governor-lael-brainard-rumored-frontrunner-biden-treasury?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Remember This Person
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Under U.S. Secretary of State Lael Brainard testifies during a hearing before the House Ways and Means Committee" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8zMDg0L2xhZWxfYnJhaW5hcmQuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Alex Wong/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It's Lael Brainard, a Fed governor and <a href="https://www.politico.com/news/2020/11/07/joe-biden-cabinet-picks-possible-choices-433431?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rumored frontrunner</a> to become Joe Biden's Treasury secretary pick. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Highlights from a lengthy résumé:</strong> Harvard PhD, adviser to President Clinton, Brookings fellow, and a couple Treasury roles under Obama, including as the department's top global diplomat. She joined the Federal Reserve in 2014 and recently helped implement its emergency lending program.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">While Brainard has won praise from the left for resisting banking regulation rollbacks, she's largely viewed as a <a href="https://fortune.com/2020/11/09/biden-cabinet-treasury-secretary-who-is-lael-brainard/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">moderate pick</a>. And that might be key to getting her through Senate confirmation: "She doesn't upset anyone too much," Politico reports. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">If picked...</strong>Brainard would be the first woman to head the Treasury. As top economic advisor to the president, she'd be responsible for steering the U.S. out of a recession, crafting a new stimulus deal, and bumping elbows with her old desk buddy, Fed Chair Jerome Powell. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Her departure would leave the Fed's board, already two members short, with just four governors—all Republican. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">If she isn't...</strong>other folks reportedly under consideration include Ariel Investments co-CEO Mellody Hobson, Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic, and Powell's predecessor, Janet Yellen. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
STARTUPS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/10/virtual-events-startup-hopin-vaults-past-2-billion-valuation?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Hopin Loser, We’re Raising Money
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, virtual events startup Hopin announced it <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/11/10/hopin-raises-125m-for-its-online-events-platform-on-the-back-of-surging-growth/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">raised $125 million</a> at a valuation of more than $2 billion. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory: </strong>Londoner Johnny Boufarhat was <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/1e2d3a60-5a04-4c9a-aa54-b4def73adcab?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">homebound</a> for two years after falling sick. As we've all learned recently, Netflix can only sustain you for so long, and he was itching for a way to network online. So last year, he launched Hopin, which recreates almost every part of an in-person event, from Twitch-like keynote presentations to Chatroulette-like networking functions. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Then Covid-19 arrived and so did blazing-fast growth</strong>. Catapulted by social distancing mandates, Hopin went from four employees at the beginning of 2020 to over 200 now and it’s targeting 800 in 2021. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Hopin also says it's profitable, with annual recurring revenue of $20 million. Users? Over 3.5 million. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Those metrics make it one of the fastest-growing startups ever. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>with Monday's <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/09/pfizers-covid19-vaccine-posts-promising-results?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">encouraging news</a> about a potential Covid-19 vaccine, it's possible live events will return sooner than we thought. But Hopin's betting it can find a foothold in a post-Covid economy with "hybrid" events. </p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">These are the <a href="https://www.dezeen.com/2020/11/08/norway-passport-design-neue-studio/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">new Norweigan passports</a>, developed by the design studio Neue. Why are we showing them to you? Because a) they are undeniably hot and b) it offers a segue to a trivia question.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Which is this: </strong>The exteriors of the new Norweigan passport are red, white, and blue to reflect the colors of Norway’s flag. Which of the following flags is <em>not </em>red, white, and blue? </p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Israel</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>United Kingdom</span></li>

\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eWe're experiencing what Wall Street wonks call a \"\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/09/stock-market-futures-open-to-close-news.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erotation\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\"—when investors sell off shares in a certain type of company and pile into another category. max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eJeffrey Greenberg/Education Images/Universal Images Group via Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eConsidering we can't even keep track of our wallets, it's not particularly surprising humans have struggled to understand how an invisible menace like the coronavirus spreads across the population.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut a \u003ca href=\"https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-020-03140-4?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estudy\u003c/a\u003e published yesterday in Nature offers new clues about Covid-19's favorite places to jump hosts.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe main takeaways\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003col\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIndoor spaces = the most risky. \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eCrowded indoor venues, such as restaurants, gyms, and cafes, accounted for the majority of the transmission. Of those, restaurants were by far the riskiest place for infections (4x more dangerous than gyms and coffee shops), the report's senior author, Jure Leskovec, told reporters. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe class divide: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003ePeople who live in lower-income areas were also \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-11-10/covid-superspreader-risk-is-linked-to-restaurants-gyms-hotels?sref=KkPzpZvz\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emore likely\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e to be infected with Covid-19, according to the research. Not only were they less likely to work from home, but also the indoor venues they visited were more crowded. For example, the average grocery store in poorer neighborhoods had 59% more hourly visitors per sq. ft. than locations in more affluent areas. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ol\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eQuick note on methodology: \u003c/strong\u003eUsing anonymized smartphone data, the researchers tracked the movements of 98 million people in 10 U.S. metros from March to May—the first wave of the virus. They superimposed this data on top of Covid-19 case numbers to \u003ca href=\"http://washingtonpost.com/health/2020/11/10/coronavirus-restaurants-gyms-hotels-risk/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecreate a model\u003c/a\u003e that simulated coronavirus infections. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhy the study matters\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBecause it can inform how leaders confront the recent surge in cases, which are now well above 100,000/day in the U.S. Should we lock it all down again? \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThese researchers argue that probably won't be necessary, because limiting capacity at indoor venues can meaningfully contain the spread of the virus—when paired with critical precautions like social distancing and wearing masks. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIn the Chicago area, limiting capacity at 20% cut down predicted new infections by more than 80%.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOn the other hand, reopening indoor businesses at full capacity = recipe for superspreading. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eWhile these researchers call for a nuanced approach to reopening the economy, public officials may find it easier to wield a blunt instrument. NYC Mayor Bill de Blasio \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/11/10/world/covid-19-coronavirus-live-updates?type=styln-live-updates\u0026label=virus\u0026index=0\u0026action=click\u0026module=Spotlight\u0026pgtype=Homepage#research-using-spring-cellphone-data-in-10-us-cities-could-help-influence-officials-facing-rising-cases-and-possible-restriction\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewarned\u003c/a\u003e of \"a lot more restrictions\" in the event of a style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, Apple \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/10/apple-event-live-updates.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" In a virtual event called \"One More Thing,\" the tech giant released its latest slate of Mac computers featuring the M1 chips it created in-house—a major departure from tapping Intel for chips, which Apple had done since 2005. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eCEO Tim Cook has been steering the ship toward the Isle of Homemade Chips for years; the company \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnet.com/news/apples-new-macbook-and-mac-mini-computers-could-change-pcs-as-we-know-them-one-more-thing-event-new-silicon/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epoured\u003c/a\u003e over a decade of R\u0026D and at least $1 billion in acquisitions into the effort. The M1 is more like the chips that power the iPhone than previous versions, which \u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2020/11/10/heres-everything-apple-announced-at-the-one-more-thing-event-today/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emeans\u003c/a\u003e apps developed for iPhones can now be used on Macs. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eNow for the fun, shiny things: \u003c/strong\u003eThe new hardware includes a super-thin MacBook Air, a new MacBook Pro with juiced-up battery life, and a Mac Mini desktop. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe new Big Sur OS also drops today.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eNow for the fun, giggly things\u003c/strong\u003e: Actor/comedian/national treasure John Hodgman style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSingles Day was created by Alibaba execs Jack Ma and Daniel Zhang as a foil to Valentine's Day. We feel even lonelier now. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAlibaba kicked sales off a little early this year, and as of 12:30am local time, \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/travel-virus-outbreak-global-trade-shopping-hong-kong-62b6c606c4dff0d2b9914770883cf6dc?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003econsumers spent\u003c/a\u003e $56.3 billion on its Taobao and Tmall e-commerce platforms. To move all that product around, Alibaba's logistics arm has prepped 3,000 chartered flights and cargo ships, 3 million logistics workers, and 10,000 mobile lockers. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eThe pandemic pushed more Chinese consumers to e-commerce, and Singles Day will provide more intel on the health of the Chinese economy. href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/11/07/joe-biden-cabinet-picks-possible-choices-433431?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003erumored frontrunner\u003c/a\u003e to become Joe Biden's Treasury secretary pick. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHighlights from a lengthy résumé:\u003c/strong\u003e Harvard PhD, adviser to President Clinton, Brookings fellow, and a couple Treasury roles under Obama, including as the department's top global diplomat. She joined the Federal Reserve in 2014 and recently helped implement its emergency lending program.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhile Brainard has won praise from the left for resisting banking regulation rollbacks, she's largely viewed as a \u003ca href=\"https://fortune.com/2020/11/09/biden-cabinet-treasury-secretary-who-is-lael-brainard/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emoderate pick\u003c/a\u003e. And that might be key to getting her through Senate confirmation: \"She doesn't upset anyone too much,\" Politico reports. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIf picked...\u003c/strong\u003eBrainard would be the first woman to head the Treasury. As top economic advisor to the president, she'd be responsible for steering the U.S. out of a recession, crafting a new stimulus deal, and bumping elbows with her old desk buddy, Fed Chair Jerome Powell. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHer departure would leave the Fed's board, already two members short, with just four governors—all Republican. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIf she isn't...\u003c/strong\u003eother folks reportedly under consideration include Ariel Investments co-CEO Mellody Hobson, Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic, and Powell's predecessor, Janet Yellen. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, virtual events startup Hopin announced it \u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2020/11/10/hopin-raises-125m-for-its-online-events-platform-on-the-back-of-surging-growth/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eraised $125 million\u003c/a\u003e at a valuation of more than $2 billion. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory: \u003c/strong\u003eLondoner Johnny Boufarhat was \u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/1e2d3a60-5a04-4c9a-aa54-b4def73adcab?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehomebound\u003c/a\u003e for two years after falling sick. As we've all learned recently, Netflix can only sustain you for so long, and he was itching for a way to network online. So last year, he launched Hopin, which recreates almost every part of an in-person event, from Twitch-like keynote presentations to Chatroulette-like networking functions. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThen Covid-19 arrived and so did blazing-fast growth\u003c/strong\u003e. Catapulted by social distancing mandates, Hopin went from four employees at the beginning of 2020 to over 200 now and it’s targeting 800 in 2021. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHopin also says it's profitable, with annual recurring revenue of $20 million. Users? Over 3.5 million. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThose metrics make it one of the fastest-growing startups ever. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ewith Monday's \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/09/pfizers-covid19-vaccine-posts-promising-results?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eencouraging news\u003c/a\u003e about a potential Covid-19 vaccine, it's possible live events will return sooner than we thought.
